follow something ↔ up.translation[0].def: to find out more information about something and take action if necessary
The police take people’s statements and then follow them up.
to do something in addition to what you have already done in order to make it more likely to succeed
This experiment was quickly followed up by others using different forms of the drug.
If there is no response to your press release, follow it up with a phone call.
follow something ↔ up.translation[1].def: something that is done to make sure that earlier actions have been successful or effective
preventative treatment and follow-up several weeks later
a book, film, article etc that comes after another one that has the same subject or characters
Spielberg says he’s planning to do a follow-up next year.
a follow-up to their hit album
follow something ↔ up.translation[2].def: done in order to find out more or do more about something
a follow-up study on children and poverty
follow something ↔ up.translation[3].def: to do something as a result of something someone has suggested or something you have found out
Many of the report’s recommendations are worth following up.
follow something ↔ up.translation[4].def: a follow-up letter, visit etc is done to make sure that earlier actions have been effective or successful, or to continue a plan of action that was started earlier
By lunchtime, I usually know how many follow-up letters, informational packets, and other documents that I need to send out to clients.
Follow-up interviews have indicated that the advertising campaign was widely misunderstood.
follow something ↔ up.translation[5].def: something that is done to make sure that earlier actions have been effective or successful, or to continue a plan of action that was started earlier
Ask one of the sales reps if we have sent a follow-up yet.
I know that the email was flagged for follow-up.
